unnormalised: Builders in Bengaluru are facing a tough time these days, what with the rising cost of cement and steel. A standard bag of cement, you know the 50 kg one, is now costing upwards of Rs. 450 in some areas. Steel prices? Don't even get me started! They've shot up to around Rs. 75,000 per ton. Imagine the impact on those building their dream homes!
normalised: Builders in Bengaluru are facing a tough time these days, what with the rising cost of cement and steel. A standard bag of cement, you know the fifty kilogram one, is now costing upwards of rupee four hundred and fifty in some areas. Steel prices? Don't even get me started! They've shot up to around rupee seventy five thousand per ton. Imagine the impact on those building their dream homes!

unnormalised: And it's not just the big materials that are getting pricier. Sand, which we get by the cubic meter (or m3), is also up by nearly 20% since last quarter. Add to that the cost of labor, which is calculated per sq ft of construction, and you're looking at a significant jump in overall building expenses.
normalised: And it's not just the big materials that are getting pricier. Sand, which we get by the cubic meter, is also up by nearly twenty percent since last quarter. Add to that the cost of labor, which is calculated per square foot of construction, and you're looking at a significant jump in overall building expenses.

unnormalised: The government’s promising infrastructure projects are also impacting material availability. I was talking to a contractor yesterday; he mentioned the difficulty in procuring aggregates, like gravel and crushed stone. You need these in huge volumes, measured in cubic meters too, for road laying and other major works. This increased demand is pushing prices further north.
normalised: The government’s promising infrastructure projects are also impacting material availability. You need these in huge volumes, measured in cubic meters too, for road laying and other major works. This increased demand is pushing prices further north.

unnormalised: Many smaller contractors are now considering delaying projects. I heard one say he’s postponing a 1200 sq ft bungalow construction because the estimated budget has already overshot by almost 15%. Can you imagine? That's a lot of money!
normalised: Many smaller contractors are now considering delaying projects. I heard one say he’s postponing a one thousand two hundred square foot bungalow construction because the estimated budget has already overshot by almost fifteen percent. Can you imagine? That's a lot of money!

unnormalised: So, if you're planning to build or renovate, best prepone your plans if possible. Construction costs aren't likely to come down anytime soon. Better factor in a buffer of at least 20% over the initially quoted price. You’ll thank me later!
